message_1: Suppose that p represents the statement "It is sunny today" and q represents the statement "I will go to the beach". Using propositional logic, combination of p and q, find the truth value of the following statement: "It is sunny today and I will go to the beach, or it is not sunny today."
message_2:
To find the truth value of the given statement, we need to break it down into its propositional logic components. The statement can be represented as:

(p ∧ q) ∨ ¬p

Here, "∧" represents the "and" operator, "∨" represents the "or" operator, and "¬" represents the "not" operator.

Now, we need to consider the possible truth values of p and q:

1. If p is true (it is sunny today) and q is true (I will go to the beach), then the statement becomes:

   (T ∧ T) ∨ ¬T = T ∨ F = T (True)

2. If p is true (it is sunny today) and q is false (I will not go to the beach), then the statement becomes:

   (T ∧ F) ∨ ¬T = F ∨ F = F (False)

3. If p is false (it is not sunny today) and q is true (I will go to the beach), then the statement becomes:

   (F ∧ T) ∨ ¬F = F ∨ T = T (True)

4. If p is false (it is not sunny today) and q is false (I will not go to the beach), then the statement becomes:

   (F ∧ F) ∨ ¬F = F ∨ T = T (True)

So, the given statement is true in three out of four possible scenarios. However, without knowing the actual truth values of p and q, we cannot determine the exact truth value of the statement.
